Key Arguments: The legislation would suppress intelligent debate and critical thinking.
It could stifle attempts to speak out against governmental and institutional corruption.
The bill lacks clarity on who determines what constitutes misinformation or disinformation.
The submission process for the bill is inadequate and suppressive.
The government and certain organizations would be exempt from accusations of misinformation.
Existing laws already cover hate speech and incitement to violence.
The bill could conflate free speech with hate and violence.
Historical examples of misinformation by governments and media are cited as concerns.
Notable Quotes: This bill is a blatant attempt to suppress and control social media in order to suppress and control genuine participation by Australians in the processes of government through the free exchange of ideas.

It is (a) totally redundant, (b) the abject antithesis of democracy, (c) in direct contravention of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (to which Australia is a signatory), as well as Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and (d) clearly a deliberate and intentional pathway to totalitarianism.
